threads.com:
We encourage you to have a look around the catalog first to see what we’re all about before posting your first thread. Topics typically posted here include:
>Outdoor recreational activities (Hiking, trail running, bushwhacking, camping, spelunking, geocaching, orienteering, expeditions, urban exploration, backpacking, etc.)
>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Most topics related to the outdoors are fine. Write properly, behave politely, encourage a respectful community, and most importantly, GO OUTSIDE!!

>>2500630
>Can i use a goretex hardshell instead of a softshell in meantime so I can save some money on buying the soft?
Not for same stuff, but IMHO you should own a WP jacket over softshell. Wear a fleece as shell layer, if it's not raining.
>What's the difference anyway?
Basically what you stated. Softhsell has no membrane, thus "soft" shell. Softshell is not waterproof, but will keep wind and light rain away. Softhsell also actually breathes, no membrane actually does.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I was converted to using trekking poles when needed while training for Mt. Whitney last year. I absolutely change the length depending on the terrain. This weekend they saved my idiot life.
There's a monster desert mountain ridgeline trail near me, with huge drops on either side, rocks and cactus everywhere, and the narrow trail gets wildly overgrown. It's a huge climb up to it, then it constantly goes up and down thousands of feet the whole time, and then you have to come back down an insanely steep canyon trail.
>brother and I tried to hike this ridge as boy scouts decades ago
>literal retards in troop slowed us all down so we had to bail down a side canyon
>brother wants revenge
>I decide to go without training
>halfway through, my quads decide they're done, so ascending becomes very slow
>make it to the end of the ridge
>start descending basically vertical canyon
>poles keep me stable but even with them each step down is very painful
>thousands of steps down and about 3 miles to go
>make it

Poles aren't always necessary or helpful and aren't some magic bullet, but use the right tools for the job.

Feel free to post tobaccos (no weed allowed), pipes, collections, pics of favorite combos for going /out/, pics of what you're doing with your pipe and any questions you might have.

Want to get into smoking pipes without spending too much cash?
Get a corncob pipe and a pouch of either Captain Black or Half and Half tobacco, available at most drugstores.
What you'll need: pipe, tobacco, lighter or matches, pipe cleaners, and either a regular old nail or a pipe tool (combination tamper, scoop, and small pick).
All of these together should run you less than $25, still. God help you.

Having trouble keeping your pipe lit? Fill it with less tobacco and smoke it slower than you think you need to, lightly tamping as needed when the smoke starts thinning out.

last_replies.com:
>>2500203
It’s definitely a poor design for the US, but not because it isn’t “sturdy.” A-frames originated in Northern Europe it quickly became more popular in parts of the US as winter retreats. Having a star tire that’s all room maximizes the amount of radiant heating it receives from the sun, warming the inside. They’re extremely hot in most of the US during the summer, and any with a loft will be intolerable. The steep roof means there’s no worry about snow load.

OP should look into a Tuff Shed. They’re small site built structures that come as a kit, with delivery and construction priced in. They used to sell actual dwelling kits, some that were two stories and had garages, but have moved away from that and now only seem to offer small sizes. They’re not insulated or finished on the inside.

It is cheaper to buy all of the materials and build one yourself. You have to weigh the materials cost, your lack of know-how, the time it will take you, the hassle of most likely doing all of the work yourself, the tools you might not have, and the pride of having built it against just buying one and having it up in a day or two but possibly being rushed by the cheapest bidder. You’ll still have to insulate and finish the inside.

House kits were super popular in the late 19th century in rural areas (“the Wild West”). There are still a few companies making them, but they’re usually legit houses rather than single room cabins. And they all seem outrageously expensive for what they are.

threads.sub: Fly fishing noob. Need advice. Want to get set up for under $100 or so.
threads.com: Oldfag here who’s been spinfishing since forever but I’m living in a fly fishing Mecca of sorts and I’ll be retiring soon and want to take up the hobby but not invest too much in tackle. Any decent combos to recommend?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2500272
Fly fisherman since the 90s here. A good fly line (just the fly line, nothing else) costs about $100.

Fly fishing isn't like spincast fishing where you can just pick up a $40 Walmart Zebco rod combo and a Walmart cheapo tackle box including lures and plastics assortment and be fine. Fly fishing has arguably the highest dropout rate of any sport, and It's very difficult to learn to cast properly with a super-cheap rod and line. You're setting yourself up for almost certain failure with that "I still think in 1970s dollars" budget that's lower than one person's weekly grocery bill these days.

The cheapest decent reel (that I personally own) is the Piscifun Sword, which is made in China and costs $40, but the reel is often the least important part of a fly fishing setup. The rod is most important, followed by the line.

My advice is that you can't afford fly fishing and might as well save yourself the $100 you'll almost certainly end up wasting when you get frustrated and drop out of fly fishing.

Don't get me wrong: Fly fishing doesn't have to cost thousands and thousands to get into, but $100 is delusional.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2500272
If you're going for salmon you'll need a more expensive setup but if you're targeting trout under a 20 inches you really only need one of those cheap rod+reel+gear kits you can pick up at a local store, with most trout you can just strip them in and not even use the reel.

Upgrade to the tryhard expensive gear once you get the hang of it

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Also start with dry fly fishing with a floating line, easiest form of fly fishing plus you can target trout by watching where they rise, where I live June is the best time to watch for trout rising in pools. You can practice your casts in your back yard by just putting on the line without a tippet of fly on. Royal wolf, muddler minnow and anything that looks like a mayfly is a good fly to start with.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2500272
I got into fly fishing last summer so i am by no means a expert, but i spent every bit of free time fly fishing and i used a cabela's bighorn 6 wt i really enjoy it and it has held up really good given that i have used it non stop and has hit so many trees rocks etc since being new to it you will hit a lot of stuff lol.
At the end of the day though i will recommend getting a good rod that is one thing not to skimp out on.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2500272
>Want to get set up for under $100 or so. Any decent combos to recommend?

not to my knowledge. If you're near a shop you might check consignment deals or find used gear for cheap at estate sales or something.

Fly fishing is expensive. If you enjoy it at all, your $100-200 entry level rod will quickly become inadequate, and might be a hindrance to your enjoyment of the sport in the short term. $400 for the orvis clearwater setup sized to your local water, probably a 3-5 weight rod(guessing PA is fly fishing "mecca"). Before long you might want different sized rods for different sized water.

Fly lines are $80-100 and are basically consumables where you may get 1-4 years use. You need tapered leaders which are $5-10 a piece and may last weeks or months. You need spools of tippet at $10+/spool. Nippers/forceps $10+/- Waders and boots at least $100, more like $400+ these days.

Then there are flies. They can cost from $.75 a fly to $10+ a fly. You can lose them in an instant in the trees while casting. You can buy flies but that quickly becomes bothersome when you want a specific fly that can't be found or you don't like spending $3 for a fly which contains $.35 of materials.

If you're pretty certain you'll stick with it, spend money on a decent setup at $300-400 or more and you'll probably end up enjoying it a lot more a few years from now. If you're not certain, find a local fly shop and book a guided trip that supplies all the gear and make sure you're certain. Then go in to the shop and cast a bunch of rods and different price points and see. If you can't test out the $100 kits, probably best to steer clear.

Do I need to go to school or have experience to do forestry?

Do all the workers have to put out fires? Can you work only during certain seasons?

Is it worth the pay if you have no experience (so they will pay you less)?

Is it worth doing just to try if you don’t want an entire career out of it?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Following to get updates!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2500269
>Do I need to go to school or have experience to do forestry?
No, but you'll be apply against people that do have those. I applied to be a Park Ranger and couldn't even get that.
>Do all the workers have to put out fires? Can you work only during certain seasons?
From what they told me in the interview, most of the work is firefighting. Year round work, at least in my case it was.
>Is it worth the pay if you have no experience (so they will pay you less)?
According to the interview, the state sets the salary for the position and experience/college doesn't matter. It also pays about the same as working at McDonalds or Walmart.
>Is it worth doing just to try if you don’t want an entire career out of it?
That's all I wanted to do, but I didn't get the job. The interview made it pretty appealing as a career though even with the shit pay, mostly all the government benefits and how quickly you can "finish your service" and retire.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2500269
>Do I need to go to school or have experience to do forestry?
What he said
>>2500284

>Do all the workers have to put out fires? Can you work only during certain seasons?
No, but you usually have to have your 64 hour class or whatever the fuck it is now. There are seasonal positions but you have to worry about getting a call back next season, and you'll probably be stringing Christmas lights or some bullshit in the off season.
>Is it worth the pay if you have no experience (so they will pay you less)?
No, not unless you do something moderately important and even then it's not great, but damn is it fun.
>Is it worth doing just to try if you don’t want an entire career out of it?
If you can get in, fuck yeah. What you do on the fire line will be your baseline work ethic for the rest of your life. A hand crew on the fire line is probably one of the hardest jobs out there. Best job I ever had.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2498298
The big kicker to a twig stove in my opinion is how dry your fuel is.
The first time I took it out I failed to get truly dry kindling while my tinder/emergency lighters failed on me, definate morale hit. The second time while taking my car, plenty of dry kindling and good fire starters I considered that I could probably maintain a solid burn with some damper wood but would need to reserve bone-dry kindling as a base for the next few fires.

I'd say take it with you if you're sure you can take/forage good dry wood, otherwise maybe have a backup if your loadout can manage it.

>>2499055
The stove itself is essential desu, we're doing a road trip of distilleries and peaks around Scotland for three weeks in January. We'll be operating out of a car so weight isn't an issue.
We did this a few years ago and didn't have a great time because it was so cold and wet, but we pushed through it (and we used a very expensive tent which was utter dogshit). I'm just seeing if some creature comforts can be added.
All hot tents in the UK seem to be DIY jobs of old ponchos for 1 person, or have a price comparable to the Savotta Hiwu. The Hiwu caught my attention because weather in Finland certainly is harsher than in Scotland so it'll definitely hold up, plus the sides have two angles so there's better usage of corner space, and there are some British retailers: a local store has 3 in stock (weirdly they aren't listed as a retailer on Savotta's website...). Plus it fits 4 people comfortably which is how many are coming.
I'd just buy the two halves, my friend already has a stove to use which is certainly tall enough (the stacking flue is like 4 metres if all parts are used and has a spark arrestor), and I'd just use tybek as a groundsheet.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2496582
>triple stitching is BETTER than single or double
sure i will agree, but gear actually designed for what you're doing is better than gear that isn't.
let's use pants as an example. sure some military pants might be triple stitched and rugged but the crotch area is still going to be sewn together like picrel. using a stock photo of jeans for convenience, the stitching pattern's just about the same. fine for walking, but it will be the first point of failure if you climb or cycle in them. my hiking pants from a recreational company were designed with these things in mind and have a gusseted crotch and won't prematurely blow out. pants with a standard pattern develop holes in the crotch really quickly from either of these activities. yes my pants might *only* be double stitched but they will last much longer because they're designed for what i use them for.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Salt lake is worth visiting if you want to ski. It's ok for a city, but you've still got hobos and crackheads like anywhere else. St George is better. There are hardly any hobos there and they have like 8 state parks, some of which rival national parks. South Utah (the lower half of the state) has the best camping and hiking. I used to live by Kanab. It's just windy all day every day but not much in the way of snow unless you're in the forest. You get more snow up north on the whole, but less wind. Down south you get more wind and less snow. It gets hotter in the south, but it's bearable, plus there is plenty of water to fuck around in.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I lived in Las Vegas for a few decades and can speak about the southern half of Utah. The temperature in St. George is only a few degrees cooler than Vegas so highs of roughly 100 F in summer and lows of 30-35 F in winter. They have Bryce Canyon and Zion, both national parks and both worth visiting but crowded. There is also Lake Powell and the North Rim of the Grand Canyon although I've never been to either one.

By far my favorite place was the Dixie National Forest just east of Cedar City. While most of Southern Utah is semi-arid, most of the DNF is on a plain at roughly 10,000 feet and consequently more alpine. There are two larger lakes there, Panguitch and Navajo, both with a good deal of trout. Not much in the way of backpacking, the Dixie National Forest is ideal for camping because you can pull off anywhere and make your campsite.

threads.com:
Hi there. Not sure if anyone remembers my thread asking about the utility of using amphetamines during hiking, but I gave it a shot. Nothing too crazy happened, this doesn't end with me getting arrested or raped by the rape dwarves, but I feel like it's interesting enough to share.
I chose a really long hike that loosely followed a train line so at any time a bailout point wouldn't be *too* far away and so that I could go for as long as I could. I carried a backpack with only a few candy bars and some electrolyte powder, and 4L of water with a filter so no matter what i wouldnt dehydrate. Plus other random shit which is less important.
Here's how it went:
>wake up at 3am - want to start early so I won't be limited by dawn
>not that it's approaching summer in the southern hemisphere so i don't need to worry about temperature
>arrive at the start at 430amish and begin
>actually feel quite refreshed because i went to bed early enough to get 7 hours of sleep and debate doing it sober
>nah, i came here for a purpose. i gobble 200mg of caffeine
>an hour or two passes and i feel awake but not much else so not really different to before
>fuck it, down 5mg of plain old d-amphetamine
>distinctly feel it kicking in 15 minutes later. things feel sharper, i feel less fatigue, can maintain pace
>this feeling continues for almost 4 hours!! woah im feeling it now
>note that throughout the entirety of the hike i am occasionally having a candy bar to keep blood glucose up, sports electrolyte powder thingy to stop cramps etc. and regularly making myself drink water even if im not thirsty
>but then
>crash hard and fast. feel like i pulled an all nighter. can still keep moving but i legitimately feel like i would fall asleep if i sat down and closed my eyes
>but i still have so much longer to go!
>so naturally i have another 200mg caffeine and 5mg of the good stuff cuz i aint done
>feel good for a while again but not to the same level
>this time wears off after only 2.5ish hours...
cont

threads.com:
Got up into my first tree stand today. The ladder felt sketchy but I made it. I didnt have a harness so I know I'm stupid. I used 1000lb non climbing rope to tie a bowline around my chest/under armpits and looped that around the stand, then anchored to the bottom. If I fell I would have at least been caught on the stand, assuming I fell to the left side.

I've got a full body harness that comes with a tree strap coming, as well as 100 feet of 10.5mm UIAA rated static rope and 4 UIAA/CE rated carabiners. I figure in addition to the harness and tree strap, I'm going to make a swiss seat with a carabiner coming off the front, and then clip that into a rope tied around up near the tree belt for the full harness. I figure two harnesses should be safe and make me comfortable up there
